Comment: "...shut it down and die."

Most Catholics don't even know what the Curia is, much less know who is in that institution or group; but you want it dismantled. Maybe replace it with global representatives from the 150 or so National Conferences of Bishops representing 1.2 billion Catholics? I don't know. I haven't the answer except that it will take a long time to dismantle the Curia -- to make the unrigging successful. Bishops can do it by asserting themselves as individual national bodies, but that seems unlikely right now. Some National Conferences of Bishops, of course, are more progressive than others. In the meantime, in dealing with abuse in churches (and everywhere, really), the best route (for bringing about reform) seems to be through local civil courts, sympathetic laypeople and clerics, the press, and Pope Francis. If courts jailed a few bishops, that might help a lot, too.

Comment: The US tested 67 nuclear devices in the Marshall Islands during a 12 year period sixty years ago.  If their combined explosive power were divided evenly over that 12-year period, it would equal 1.6 Hiroshima-size explosions per day.  Not surprisingly, the Marshall Islands are by far the most contaminated place in the world.  The people of the Marshall Islands have been heavily impacted by the effects of radiation, experiencing very high levels of cancer, birth defects, and other illnesses and diseases.  

The US has a moral obligation to the people of the Marshall Islands.  It has only partially fulfilled that obligation, allowing them to enter the US freely.  The US federal government provides some financial support to states and territories with Marshallese migrants, but not nearly enough to cover the costs of services provided to them.  Hawaii has taken a compassionate stance by covering the costs of programs such as Medicaid.  That compassion should be extended to legal immigrants.

In my experience people who grew up then completely forget how much benefit they received, and like to pretend that they were just harder working, or that people today are just lazy. Comment: Very well said, Laurie. 

Governor Brown has the best interests of our state in mind with this endorsement. 

Measure 97 affects corporations that do at least $25 mil./yr. in Oregon sales. Currently, Oregon is 50th, dead last, in corporate taxes in relation to total taxes. We have no sales tax. That makes our goods and services a bargain. 

People who don't work in schools don't realize just how much we lost in the last recession. We are still dealing with its effects, including large class sizes. Many of our first- and second-graders will struggle throughout their years in school. 

Oregon's boom-or-bust way of funding schools needs to change. We need more stable funding, including being able to set aside money for those times when the national economy is in recession. 

If this measure passes, it will have a profound effect on our options during a recession. Ultimately, we will have better educated children. This benefits everyone, including businesses.

Comment: The basic principle that governed voting in colonial America was that voters should have a "stake in society." Leading colonists associated democracy with disorder and mob rule, and believed that the vote should be restricted to those who owned property or paid taxes. Only these people, in their view, were committed members of the community and were sufficiently independent to vote. Each of the thirteen colonies required voters either to own a certain amount of land or personal property, or to pay a specified amount in taxes. 

This rule was in effect for over 100 years. This country would be in a much better place if we had stuck to this system. Too many people are transient in this country, most home owners only stay 5-7 years and then move. They don't develop a sense of community with there neighbors and towns. People who live in Apartments or just rent don't pay there share of taxes but get the full benefit of other peoples money in services. Own land Vote, renters no vote.

Comment: I think the result of such an analysis depends heavily on your definition of "fake news".  Presenting falsehoods as if they are facts is the obvious definition, but there are many other shades of "fake news": Articles that ignore any inconvenient facts that may exist in order to promulgate a pre-existing agenda, Articles that present negative hypothetical outcomes based on events that haven't taken place yet, or Articles that imply something as a fact based on a few social media snippets that the author claims to be indicative of worldwide public opinion.  Frankly it takes a very objective and dedicated editorial director to avoid publishing fake news and unfortunately those people were among the very first to be laid off during the last three decades of the media's decline.

Especially if they're taking prescribed medications. Bullying people and threatening them with incarceration is only going to cause depression and make their problem worse. There is no magic treatment fix. Addicts have to have will power and a strong and positive support system that helps them regain the will to live.

 And then there's the falling real wages(and benefits) coupled with ever higher housing and medical costs. Lots of stress baked in. 
We have a two-tiered economy (began in earnest in the early 2000's) with a growing higher-end tier that doesn't really care what 70% or so of the population can afford, it will do just fine marketing to the 30% are doing fine. The lower tier simply exists on volume sales to the masses.

Comment: I am from Pendeton, OR and lost my employment when the state decided to close the psychiatric hospital here.  Tax payers should be outraged by this, as the closure of this facility wastes all the tax dollars spent constructing this hospital.  Not to mention the thousands of dollars that were spent moving employees from Pendleton if they decided to uproot their families in order to keep their state employment.  This of course does nothing to account for the lost tax revenue from the future wages earned by these employees and the dollars that they spend annually in the community.  

In addition to all of this, what tax payers don't realize is that the cost to the state when a mentally ill person is waiting for a bed is much, much higher per day than what it costs in a state operated facility.  That is a lot of money wasted in one form or another on the romantic notion of deinstitutionalization but the reality is that there are truly ill individuals out there that need that type of care.

Since, I have read thousands of research papers on lead toxicology, it begs a lot of thought about what was, what could have been, and concerns for the minds of the grandchildren now going through school.... and for their future grandchildren. We have known for more than a thousand years of the poisonous nature of lead exposures, yet we really don't behave as if we learn from many of these hints of how to move toward a better more sane future. I guess that that fits the nature of accumulative effects of lead on learning abilities.

Therefore, the annulment is only a piece of paper and those 4 bishops were only pretending.
Vincent Van Son Nguyen

Comment: There's no question that the POTUS has broad constitutional authority to ensure the safety of the USA and its citizens. However it's completely unjustified for the Trump spokesperson to say that the judiciary can't rule on that order. In fact, it's precisely their job to rule on it if the order is challenged.

The reason why the order was challenged wasn't because it's a treaty or human rights violation. It was challenged by the states of Minnesota and Washington on the grounds that the order contravened states' financial rights. And in fact, it's clear that Trump's order would have a financial impact on some states. The legal question, however, is whether Trump's power to prioritize national security outweighs the rights of states to control aspects of their financial independence. I suggest that, especially given the temporary nature of Trump's order, that the final decision will be in his favour.

Comment: I may be the weak link here but I never once even considered doing Resurrection Pass in one day. I always reserved the cabin at Devil's Pass and spent a night there...usually with friends of course. Once we let in another party into the cabin due to a brown bear roaming around. I am not a super mountain biker so I need that cabin to rest, relaxed and eat. Its a great journey as well if you are not rushing through it. I know guys who hike the Chilkoot in one day, ran through Crow Pass and all that but part of being in the outdoor is to enjoy what it has to offer. I did Resurrection Pass several times over and each trip was unique and special even if the trail was exactly the same as I remembered it. Probably hasn't change since my last time, I bet.

Comment: No and yes.
I think the measure around passive income closes a loophole in which corporations are used primarily to shelter investment income.  The higher taxes are only on the investment income.  If you're saving money in a savings account a few months a year and taking it out of the savings account to pay your staff during slow periods, you're not going to be paying a lot of tax on the interest you're earning, and you can get around this by using a line of credit and deducting the interest payments your company pays instead of paying tax on the income your company earns.  You can even personally loan your company the money and have it pay you the interest.

Comment: Mushers who compete in the Iditarod don't kill their dogs who don't make the cut (culling).  Dogs who "don't make the cut" are sold or given to good homes, or the musher keeps them as pets.  If a dog musher were to cull their dogs, we all would know this within the dog mushing community.  It simply is not true.  This does not mean that has never happened before -- many, many years ago, culling was considered an acceptable practice -- but that is outdated thinking of long ago and it is not practiced by  mushers today. Mushers love their dogs.

Well, I have, and he is a good race director who works very hard to be fair.  If there are problems to be solved, I am sure the mushers and the ITC will work together to resolve them. Comment: Accepting what you say as the basic theological orientation of those who object to AL, their position is still easily countered from within their own frame of reference. They do indeed argue that "....anyone who approaches the sacrament in the state of sin does so unworthily (borrowing a Pauline phrase) and commits a sin." And they go on to assert that a remarried divorcee is objectively living in a state of mortal sin. What they do not acknowledge is that, based on their own orthodox reasoning, such a state only applies under 3 conditions: 1) grave or serious matter (tick); 2) full knowledge of what they are doing (maybe tick); and 3) full consent of the will. The whole point of the AL footnote is to address those whose lives are in a murky mess: extricating themselves from their relationship and/or living a brother-sister relationship is very complicated if not infeasible. There is no full consent of the will. By traditional standards of reasoning, communion is valid in such cases.

Comment: Sessions was forced to recuse him from federal Russia investigations after The Washington Post reported that the former Alabama senator had met twice with the Russian ambassador, even though he testified during his confirmation hearing in January that he “did not have communications with the Russians.” Later, it was revealed that there was a third undisclosed meeting.

On Jan. 17, Sen. Patrick J. Leahy (D-Vt.) asked Sessions in a letter: “Several of the President-Elect’s nominees or senior advisers have Russian ties. Have you been in contact with anyone connected to any part of the Russian government about the 2016 election, either before or after Election Day?”

Sessions replied, “No.” This answer has been proven to be false.

18 U.S. Code 1001 applies to the Leahy letter even if Sessions’s responses to the senator weren’t sworn. This statute prohibits falsifying or hiding information or providing materially false or fraudulent information to the government — even if not under oath.

Were all of our ancestors running from tigers or some other menace 2-3 times per week (for 2.5 minutes each time, to achieve maximum fitness)? For millennia, carbs in the form of grains, corn or roots have been an essential part of our diet.

Comment: Unfortunately, the realities of the post-Cold War world mean naval replacements are low priority. The Navy is virtually unchallenged on the seas, and most of these ships have received technology upgrades over their lives. Priority has been given to 21st-century flagships like the Ford-class carrier, America-class amphibious assault ship and the Virginia-class nuclear fast-attack sub. A foray into littoral vessels has also ate into the budget.

The planned replacement for the Burkes, the Zumwalt-class radically inflated to $4.1B/unit and was cut to just 3 ships. 22 new Flight III Burkes are envisioned to replace older Burkes and Ticos and be the predominant surface warship for the next couple decades until a new Destroyer program bears fruit. There's no plans for a Cruiser replacement after the Ticos are phased out.

Modern budget realities and acquisition timelines are just too long to see major change anytime before the mid 2030s.

Comment: I'm sure you were raised to listen to and respect authority.  Most Americans were.   So much so that psychologist Stanley Milgram devised the "Milgrim experiment."   I cannot summarize it sufficiently here, but Milgram was attempting to study the effect of authority figures on ordinary people from all walks of life.   This was in the 60s when the Eichmann trial was international news, and the question of how Nazi Germany could have occurred was questioned by most people in the world.  

Milgram didn't express his conclusions in the exact way I do, but essentially the Milgram experiment proved that 2 out of every 3 people will kill someone they know nothing about just because another person they know nothing about told them to, if the third party appeared to authoritative, i.e., wore a white coat, made notes and directed the experiment. 

I think that experiment is one of the most compelling ever.

Comment: Video and audio recordings are not perfect.  However, video and audio recordings are by far the best way to obtain truth and justice.  Overwhelming evidence in favor of video and audio recordings is the cell phone video shown on the news of police/citizen encounters, kids getting hit by vehicles when getting off a bus, and crimes being committed.  Even the police gather video of crimes made by citizens.  Each reader of this article can decide whether the reader would rather have the video recording or not have the video recording in figuring out what happened in an incident.  If a jury is presented with video and testimonial evidence, the jury will almost certainly use the video to decide the case because jurors will see the evidence with their own eyes and will trust it more than testimony filtered through a person's brain into words.  Both video and audio recordings should be made mandatory for police officers in Alaska to promote the search for truth and justice.

Comment: The truth is always somewhere in the middle.  Its true that if you go to rural areas you hear all kinds of things with populist appeal.   But thats LOCAL CBC, not national CBC.  The problem with the CBC is there is no way to actually affect what is going on.  So the choice becomes either live with it, or try to do away with it completely.

I, too, teach at a college part-time, and marking and other time is covered by the hourly classroom teaching amount. The college uses an informal ratio of two or three hours for every hour in the classroom for part-timers. The issue though is with full-time faculty, they are well paid for what they do. I've done the math, and the full-timers receive, when compared on an hourly basis, way more than the part-timers, as well as, they have benefits, a pension, and lots of time off. "For the purpose of this Convention, the term "torture" means any act by which severe pain or suffering, whether physical or mental, is intentionally inflicted on a person for such purposes as obtaining from him, or a third person, information or a confession, punishing him for an act he or a third person has committed." - International Convention Against Torture

Comment: I think today will be a pivotal one for Rogoff. 
That Rogoff met with Morris Communications, and failed to broker a deal to sell the paper is telling. 
The purpose behind Chapter 11, is for the debtor to be able to keep the business alive and pay back creditors over time. 
The Rogoff Plan basically sells the paper to anyone willing to loan her a million dollars to continue status quo operations for eight weeks. 
But this plan completely misses the other half of the equation in that none of the over 200 contractors and vendors will be paid, ever, except for one, the Binkley loan of one million.
Binkley, a proposed debtor in possession has negotiated a deal to keep the presses rolling in a building owned by GCI. And because the potential buyers have no experience in the newspaper business they have hired and old timer, with a win under his belt from thirty years ago. 
None of this, the Rogoff Plan, is a plan to keep the paper alive, but to give the paper to the Binkley family for free.

Comment: This cannot be emphasized enough. 

The defacto way of gaining "residency" in Canada is through the 10 year multi entry renewable visa.  You can live here six months at a time, as long as you exit and re-enter every six months.

You can buy as many houses as you like.  You can buy businesses, farms, and commercial property. And you can raise your family here.  And yes your kids can enroll in a  public school, as long as they pay international student fees. They can even attend private schools.  You can avail yourself of all community amenities, and use the medical system.  

So in return for paying a bit more for education and paying for medical, you don't have to declare income or pay income tax. 

This is a perfect system for those who do not mind a foot in two countries.   Or who prefer it.

And yes, almost a million of these visas were issued to China in the last three years, the majority of them in the past year, so the popularity is ramping up.

Comment: Yes, I was thinking of Meera Kohler (AVEC's CEO) when I read that idea too.  AVEC's plan would run a line to all the villages and make a state-wide grid.  This would save villagers a ton of $$, and the rural school districts, and the state wouldn't have to put any more millions into PCE (power cost equalization, a subsidy for rural electricity costs).  And it would mean lower costs for electricity statewide, though not as low as if they just ran the power lines directly to the existing railbelt grid. 

However, in the long run I think a statewide grid is better because it would allow more alternative electricity generation to come online.  Western AK could produce a TON more wind power but right now it would overwhelm the tiny grids they are on.  For the same reason hooking up to the national grid would be even better, and would result in lower electricity costs in the long run.  It's all about where you put the timeline for the results you want.

Treasury Board: compensation in the private equals compensation in the public sector for the same work. 

Now your other points.
I remembered a 1980 ad in the Globe (you owe $6 billion to the special indexed public service pension plan). The same day an editorial said how unfortunate that only the public sector could afford indexing. You suggest that. I had a look. Two points.

Comment: Base load generation is already adequate in Ontario - nuclear and river run hydro.  

Peak load generation is what established grid systems value the most.  Nuclear is prohibitively expensive for peak load supply.  River run hydro is ok if it is not already being used for base load but hydro dam generation is better - there's not much of this in Ontario.  Coal is too dirty and too expensive now and not suited to peak load generation.  Renewable energy costs less than other options for peak load generation and its natural availability typically aligns with energy demand but not always.  Gas generation is the main competitor to renewables - it is very expensive but it is definitely available on short notice.  

I've read that places like Vermont, Denmark, Spain and Portugal are already using wind energy for base load generation so renewables can be used this way too.  A modernizing economy like China likely would have a greater need for new base load generation.

Comment: Another issue that has been ignored is the unfair or inequitable treatment of homeowners and other asset owners regarding income on capital gains. In a logical world all income would be taxed the same. This would include salaries, capital gains on home sales, professional income, and capital gains on stock or other asset sales. This would go a long way to take some of the heat out of the real estate and stock markets, as both are inflated assets (aka bubbles). But if one wishes to maintain the capital gains exemptions on homes, it could be made more equal if it was a once in a lifetime thing and it was only for the average value of a home in Canada at the time of the claim, so the playing field was more equitable or equal. Increasing the holding period from one year to a five year minimum, with the holder being required to have paid personal income tax in Canada for that period might also help. These are all understandable and addressable issues.

Comment: I've studied spectral absorption lines, and it's what they look like that causes me to jump up and down over the silliness presented the public. We see such a small portion of the spectrum, too.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Astronomical_spectroscopy does a decent job of initiating a student to the subject. What exoplanet searchers study would be much more complex.
It's unlike anything most people have ever seen, so the leap to what's pictured above is utter comedy. Notice the oceans and ice on E & F!
But I also grew up with TV from the fifties and understand why Gene R. "warp'd" around in space. One of my favorite STNG shows is one where a few scientists show it had consequences.
The distances in space are beyond typical comprehension, to say the least that can be said about that.
But, even with my sourpuss, I'm still fascinated by all of it, & I'm always wondering on the lies, their origin, and their purpose. We live in the lie from every direction imaginable, and then some.

Comment: I had my Grandmother's old piano in my basement and decided to see if anyone wanted it.  I advertised it online for weeks and found that no one wanted it or they were willing to haul it away for a fee.  I had had the piano tuned a number of times over the years so my daughter could play it and it had to be tuned an octave low because as soon as the tuner tightened the strings, they would snap.  The cost of restringing the piano far exceeded the value of the piano or even of replacing it with a new electronic piano.  I fully empathise with the author on how it would have been a shame to scrap the old girl and luckily I finally found a lady who was willing to take it.  It took six of us to load it up and haul it to its new home.  Old pianos, even though they are beautiful and sound wonderful have a negative value in today's world.  I am just glad that my late Grandmother's old piano has found a new home where it is still played.

Comment: I have done a cruise from Vancouver to Skagway via Alaska ferry (altho less deluxe, a great way to travel with locals on board who know a lot about the area). This year we had to go back to do the great road trip. Flew to Whitehorse, rented a car, drove to Dawson City and did a brief stint on the Dempster Highway ( Tombstone Park). Crossed the Yukon River to pick up Top of the World Highway to Poker Creek border crossing. Then on to Chicken and Tok Alaska, and down the Richardson Highway to Paxson.  Next across the Denali Highway to Cantwell and north to Denali Park.   South on the Parks highway to Wasilla and picked up the Glenn Highway and Tok cutoff back to Tok.  Crossed into Canada at Beaver Creek and followed the Alaska Highway along to Kluane Park and great view of Kluane Lake.  Also visited Kathleen Lake (Kluane Park) and then back to Whitehorse for flight south. We booked accommodation at well equipped rustic cabins for most of the trip. For two weeks, it was great scenery.

Comment: I agree with your assessment of the "hunting" philosophy of the people who killed the gray whale, but I don't agree that they couldn't tell the difference. If they abided by the hunting ethic that a hunter should identify what he/she is about to shoot before he/she shoots, they could easily tell the difference between a gray whale and a beluga. A gray whale's face is extraordinarily long due to the fact that it is a baleen whale and the gray whale is up to 50 feet in length. A beluga has a stubby face (with teeth) and the biggest beluga gets up to 18 feet. These people saw an animal in the water and didn't care what it was, they started shooting. By the time they did identify the animal as a baleen whale, it had been tortured for 90 minutes and was already bleeding to death. Again, I believe that these people poached an internationally protected species and that they should be prosecuted to the fullest extent of the law.

Comment: About a month ago, I took a 13 hour class at UAA on the Alaska economy. Several guest speaker economists and Ken Alper explained reality and here's the breakdown. Our budget is $4.3b, we have $1.3b, we need $3b. Any state consumption or state income tax would only bring in $500m each. After wrestling with the issue (among great minds I might add) the class attendees decided the only option that solves the budget crisis would be to use the dividend payout (earnings, not principle - yes your PFD) OR restructure the oil tax formula to pre 2012. Did you know our ever brilliant legislators changed the way AK is paid oil taxes from GROSS to NET profit?! And worse case scenario was $40/barrel?! One economist teaching the class speculated if the oil taxes were still paid on gross, we'd have $4b in oil tax revenue (based on actual barrel market prices) in the bank. As Robin Brena has recommended, I say we restructure back to GROSS and have a fair tax structure sans legislator favors!

Comment: Here is the thing that the article overlooks. According to TomTom's statistics Cape Town is now the most congested city in Africa, and in the top-5 worldwide. It was not like this just two years ago. In two years it went from relatively free-flowing traffic with only occasional jams in fairly predictable places that locals could easily avoid (at least, outside of tourist season) to one of the most congested cities in the world - where people now routinely need to budget 90 minutes or more to get from a home in Bellville to a job in town (not a very long distance). You can't avoid it with backroads either - they are jammed too.

What changed ? The trains stopped running reliably. We can debate why but the core of it remains: when the trains worked reasonably well, many people (including lots of white-collar workers) used them to get to work. Now all those people are using taxis or cars - and the roads simply cannot handle the extra load. We need MPT to make cars feasible.

Comment: Precisely correct, just as you get to decide for whom you will work, the baker is the only individual with the right to determine who hires him to bake a unique cake for the sole benefit of the other person at some future date.  It is called a contract; and in order for it to be a valid contract all parties must be voluntary and willing participants. Why an individual chooses not to enter into a contract is irrelevant, for the contract to be valid it must be willingly entered into or else the contract is invalid. Law students learn this in their first contract law class. Doesn't matter if the contract is to provide a custom cake on a specified date, or build a custom home to the specifications of a homeowner, or to mow a property owners lawn every Tuesday prior to sunset.  No one, since the passage of the 13th Amendment, has the right to unilaterally decide someone else must labor for their benefit involuntarily.

Comment: The federal government's argument is simple: its wardens need segregation cells to discipline inmates. Comment: COLAs are based on inflation formulas.  And they're typically applied to salary, not 401(k) contributions.

The whole point here is to get government to do what much of the private sector has already done, and done for a good reason -- phase out unpredictable and often unsustainable pension plans and switch to predictable and sustainable 401(k)-style contributions (and include employees in SS).

You're looking at it only from the employee side.  Are pensions great for employees?  Sure, at least for the employees that get all their benefits out before the system collapses.  And if the employee stays in that job for decades (feeling unable to move on when they get burnout).

They're far from great for the ones at the end that have to settle for 30 cents on the dollar from a government bailout.  And they're sure not great for taxpayers that are stuck with the bill.

Comment: A 10-day series by the Anchorage Daily News called "A People in Peril," in 1988. It came about when my editor, during which time I had just started at the ADN as a part-time obituaries writer while join to Anchorage Community College, part of UAA then, he noted a lot of deaths among young Native people without a cause cited. We knew those were suicides. So the whole staff, 17 reporters, starting in 1987, began collecting information from across Alaska. Sometime after 6-months of doing our regular reporting routines, and writing our parts, it was time for publication. My part is called; "Where is the Leadership?" The series won a Pulitzer Prize in 1988. In a paragraph, that is the quick story on that. I have on my desk today, a Pulitzer Prize Medallion for my small part. It didn't ask why, but was intended to start a conversation about the whole gamut of cultural upheaval in the Native community and resulting in a host of violence, homicides, suicides, mental illness,and others.

Comment: Allow me, as a fellow who also lived in Hong Kong in the early '90's, to add to this very interesting article. In 1984, the Joint Declaration was signed because of a quirk in history - the fact that Hong Kong island was, in perpetuity, owned by Britain but the Kowloon Peninsula was leased from the Chinese for 99 years, and therefore, by the nature of leases, either extended by the owner (in this case, China), or the property reverts back to China. 
China was in no mood to have the lease extended...so therefore there needed to be a orderly transfer of control, eventually of the entire colony (because no one believed that a Hong Kong island split from Kowloon made any sense).  The Republic of China on Taiwan seeing all of this never really bought Deng Xiaoping's idea of one country two systems to be implemented on Taiwan. So to this day, the ROC on Taiwan rejects the idea wholeheartedly. 
As so it is to this day. China can rule Hong Kong with a velvet glove, the ROC aint buying it.

Comment: Calling for changes to law on the basis of outrage or other strong emotions is unwise. Says the author:

"We also need to develop a legal, medical and social consensus around the line for capacity to consent. Men have been acquitted in cases where complainants have been staggering, slurring, even vomiting."

In effect the author is calling for a legal intoxication limit for consenting to sex, akin to the limit we put on driving a vehicle. It's an irrational solution- the kind that are often proposed on the basis of outrage- that ignores the real harm this new regime would bring.

People who break the law by engaging in non-consensual sex are already punished. Now the author wants to punish men- specifically- when they cross some arbitrary moral line. Slurred speech? That can occur between 0.07 and 0.09 BAC. Staggering can occur between 0.10 and 0.125 BAC. That's just one to two drinks. Yet the author suggests that consent is invalid at that point.

Comment: That's right, Putin, like Trump, was elected by a minority in his own nation - he had his own "electoral college" in place.

All right, we're a republic, supposedly a democratic republic where citizens vote to elect their representatives. But the representation isn't proportional, for example a Wyoming citizen's vote is worth 3.6 California votes. Gerrymandering reduces many targeted votes to near zero value in state representative elections. Voter ID and voter discouragement take the vote away from many millions of targeted Democratic voters. Nationally, Clinton won the popular vote by a fairly big margin, but the disparity in the value of an individual's vote depending on region of residence, reflected in the lopsided electoral college, put Trump in power.

Comment: I stand to be corrected, but I cannot find anywhere in the CRA advantage rules the prohibition of the following situation:

I contribute an amount to a spousal RRSP.
3 years later (after which the original investment can no longer be attributed to me), my spouse withdraws the money. My spouse has no other income and, for the purpose of this discussion, withdraws an amount that will end up being tax free (stays under their basic personal exemption).
My spouse then contributes the (now tax-free) money withdrawn from their RRSP into their TFSA.

From what I see, my spouse now has money that (was) is (my) earned income, of which there was effectively no tax paid on it, that is now in a tax free account.

Comment: Tony,

Changing the status of a union to being a "mission" does not require that the leadership be changed. For example, when I was in the Greater New York Conference in the early 80s, the conference petitioned for a status change from "conference" to "mission" for financial reasons because a mission was allowed to both retain a larger portion of funds and to receive supplemental funds. The request was denied but a solution to the funding challenge was found through other means. Basically, the petition made the financial need obvious enough to receive attention.

A Division taking-over a Union and replacing the leadership would be a drastic action with potential repercussions on a scale so large that delegates to the Annual Council would be hesitant to endorse or allow it.

Comment: Canada should be looking at targeted responses to US protectionism.

We have an oscillation goods surplus with the US, but a big and consistent service deficit.  This is mostly due to US intellectual property.  Every trade agreement with the US entrenches their hold on this IP by extending patents, copyrights, and trade secret protections.  One of the benefits of Trump's admin was its rejection of TPP, which would have greatly enhanced established (US) tech company moats.

I think that is where we can put the most pressure on the US.  IP is only as valuable as governments allow it to be, and enforcing it puts a cost on users and limits on new challengers.  Withdrawing that cooperation would reduce costs to Canadians, unlike reciprocal trade barriers.  Antitrust tools, like we've seen in Europe with Google and Microsoft, is another possible lever.  We should be making it clear that we know how to retaliate without hurting ourselves.

Comment: There's a number of worrying factors that might encourage Trump toward war, but the idea that he could use it as cover to dismiss Mueller's special counsel is probably the least likely one.

What's more concerning is the PR incentive: as the author pointed out, wars tend to cause US media to circle the wagons. Mediocre presidents suddenly seem more serious and "presidential". Trump already got a taste of that when he fired a few cruise missiles at Bashar al-Assad. For a brief period of time, Trump got the kind of fawning cable-news coverage he craved.

The other thing kind of ironic, but does relate to the Russian connection. Nothing would silence accusations about Trump's being a Russian puppet as quickly as a hot war against Russia's client state in Syria. The more political hay is made over Trump-Russia connections, the more attractive this option begins to look.

Comment: Referring to the first referendum as having failed should include the note that it only failed because the threshold for success was set at 60%.  Over 50% of British Columbians voted for electoral reform that time.

On the question of electoral reform, though, there's a serious complicating factor that this article doesn't mention, namely, that unless the BC Liberals elect one of their own as speaker, a hypothetical NDP/Green alliance does not have the votes to pass electoral reform legislation on their own.  Tradition typically dictates that in the event of a tie the speaker vote for the continuation of debate (if it's not a final passage) or for the status quo.  So an NDP/Green speaker probably would not be able to supply the deciding vote to pass a law that was otherwise 43-43.

If the NDP or the Greens had even one more seat, it would be a very different situation.

Comment: I'm very familiar with that kind of behavior at Ridgeline, Pisgah and Alton Baker Park, and it is unnerving and too often unpleasant. That's why I treat every dog owner (and runner, power walker, mountain biker, etc.) as a clueless threat, because my first priority is to protect my dog. We're not there to socialize, so our default position is always to yield. He walks in front of me, never more than four feet ahead. We'll move as far right as possible and, if necessary, off the trail to wait as you and yours pass, whether on two legs or four. We'll also back up to a spot to make that happen if there are multiple dogs. We don't care what you think of us. Just keep going.

It's a multi-use trail with lots of folks feeling entitled to do as they wish. This is Eugene, after all, and the South Hills to boot. If we keep that in mind at the start and don't pretend that our intent is somehow superior, stepping aside for a second or two or 10 seems a lot less inconvenient.

Comment: This structure was put on the beach by Castle and Cooke back in the days when you could take sand from the North Shore to construction projects on the South shore.  The dome shape was big enough enough to cover the loading bed of a truck.  A tractor would push the sand up on top of the dome.  which had a loading shoot on the top with a open/close capacity.  When the sand was pushed from the waters edge to cover the dome then the hatch was opened.  When the truck was loaded the hatch was closed and the dome was covered with sand again.   ... and again... Glen Powell  convinced Mayor Blaisdell to have it stopped [mid 50's] by getting the City to  buy the land as a Park.  Good for the life guards for keeping on this hazard and good for the City for removing it.

Comment: Between the 1840s and the 1860s  the "Know-Nothing" movement (the Native American Party or the American Party)  tried to convince the American public that Catholics were trying to take over the country.  Catholics were going to put the Pope in power and institute strict laws in compliance with Church doctrine.  There was a secondary belief the the immigrants were being brought to the country to take the jobs held by Americans. Of course most of those holding the jobs were first and second generations immigrants themselves.   
I believe there is a great parallel to today and the Know-Nothing movement. Facts give way to miss-beliefs and fear overruns common sense. While there are strong reasons to deal with illegal immigrants there is an ongoing amount of individuals who see every legal immigrant as a three to the country in some form.

Comment: Why not just emulate the ETF and buy all the banks?

Rob C and I discussed this about a year ago, with this same ETF. 

At $9.95 per trade, if you have $9,630 or more to invest in banks you will save money buying equal amounts of each bank in your brokerage account.  Then for an additional $59.70 a year you could rebalance annually. This saves money on fees AND you will earn a greater yield. 

At least one of the big 5 offers a $6.95 trade (CIBC), and if you deal with them the point at which just doing it yourself makes sense is just over $6700. 

Personally, I doubt I would bother to rebalance annually. I would save the fees and only rebalance if things got really out of balance. 

I personally hold 4 of the big 5 (I don't recognize National as a big bank) and intend to add the 5th (BMO) at some point in the future. 

I think if you don't have enough $ to hold all, either go with the highest yielding (CM) or one of the two biggest (RY,TD). Either way, I think you will be fine.

Comment: He was not a licensed facility and therefore not subject to laws regulating licensed facilities.   The law makes no provisions extending the regulations to "applicants."   A private citizen can give away less than 1 oz of cannabis.  The only legal prohibitions against giving away samples apply to trade shows.   So he did not technically violate any laws, Municipal or State.   What he did was unwise for sure, but it does not warrant anything beyond a cease and desist order from the State and an amendment to the laws which apply the regulations to applicants.   That Demboski would use this to obstruct the opening is not surprising, but it also represents the worst of the self-righteous, obstructionist attitude of some on the assembly.   The people voted and you lost, your job is to regulate not obstruct.   If you can't put aside your personal bias, then resign.   Aside from that, he quit when requested, so leave him alone and let him open.

Comment: This is the IRS language on 501C3's who push an individual for president and it's going on in Catholic Churches right now....

"Certain activities or expenditures may not be prohibited depending on the facts and circumstances.  For example, certain voter education activities (including presenting public forums and publishing voter education guides) conducted in a non-partisan manner do not constitute prohibited political campaign activity. In addition, other activities intended to encourage people to participate in the electoral process, such as voter registration and get-out-the-vote drives, would not be prohibited political campaign activity if conducted in a non-partisan manner.
On the other hand, voter education or registration activities with evidence of bias that (a) would favor one candidate over another; (b) oppose a candidate in some manner; or (c) have the effect of favoring a candidate or group of candidates, will constitute prohibited participation or intervention."

Comment: Hi John,

Construction costs are determined by the bidding process;  choosing the best qualified contractor, not the cheapest, by using a fixed price contract with a fixed completion date.  The two primary causes of cost overrun are change orders and delays beyond the contractors control.  Change orders are issued by HART when necessary, based on error or omissions in its original bid requirements.  For a $multi-billion project  that will require a couple of decades to complete, it is not possible to avoid them, and HART has  provided a contingency amount in its budget.  What it cannot anticipate is a labor strike, for example, or a law suit that shuts down the project, sometimes for years.   

HART has been subjected to  a lawsuit that shut it down for a year that severely impacted the cost of construction.  We must complete the construction of HART, and I suggested a possible way to finance it.

Rail operations and HART management are subjects for another article.

It wasn't that long ago that kids were expected to get up early, do farm chores, then walk to school  (5 miles, in the snow, up hill both ways) and were expected to be polite and keep up on school work. The being driven to activities is fairly new as well - we had to make our own games and teams when we wanted to play. And that much fresh water taken out of the Wash./Or. drainage, or even Alaska's, would certainly have considerable effect on the coastal ecology.  And how much is fresh water worth, per barrel?  And would sales be year-round?  And local storage in California?  Pump the seasonal excess into reservoirs?  I have some great sounding ideas also, but when I crunch the numbers, my parade gets rained on.

Comment: You must be quite young. Bagged milk used to be common, but it's about fifteen or twenty years since I last saw it. The four litre polyethylene jug is fairly new; when bagged milk was popular in BC the other option for large consumers was two litre plasticized cardboard cartons, which cost more per litre. I think the four litre jug displaced the bags. For many people this is unfortunate; a four litre jug is heavy when full and children and the elderly have difficulty handling it, whereas a 1.33 litre bag in a light plastic pitcher is much easier to deal with.

Comment: I paid taxes in Calgary (and in Alberta) in the 1980s and some of that tax money went to paying for the infrastructure and operations of the 1988 Olympic Winter Games. At the time I had no objections and after the success of those games I even had a bit of pride in the fact that some of my taxes had contributed to that success. Calgary, during those games. was a magical place.

My thoughts have since changed about the Olympic Winter Games. Paskapoo, a former popular low cost ski area for Calgarians,  became Canada Olympic Park (ski jumping, luge, bobsleigh), an expensive white elephant ever since. Nakiska was sold to Murray Edwards for a song. The Olympic Saddledome was quickly turned into the private fiefdom of the Calgary Flames (Murray Edwards again). To give tax money to Murray Edwards now that he is a tax refugee in London, England would be too raw for us Alberta taxpayers now. Defiling Banff National Par further with an expansion of Lake Louise ski area is a complete non-starter.

Comment: Putting aside the throwaway comments on Khadr, you put your finger on the key fissure in not just the NDP but Canadian society generally. There is a part of the economy that is dependent on resource extraction and transportation. These sectors are faltering for various reasons. We should be spending a lot more time talking about the forests than energy, but both need a lot of discussion. No party has proposed a meaningful way forward for this part of the economy and the people who dependent on it. There is a second part of the economy based on design, technology and innovation that is growing rapidly but is largely urban. This is also poorly understood but is currently thriving. Then there is a third sector that has been cut loose and is flailing. We need policies to address all three.

Comment: I think this bears repeating about Trump's role as President:

In the United States, the President is both head of government and head of state - unlike the Prime Ministers of UK, Canada, and other Commonwealth countries, who are only heads of government. 

Head of government is a political role, but head of state has been defined as "the public persona that officially represents the national unity and legitimacy of a sovereign state." 

That's why the President, having both roles, should display a certain amount of decorum - instead of engaging in crude twitter battles with tv personalities. 

It's a lesson that American students learn in elementary school civics classes.
